Praises University Students

"Gentlemen," he began, "I appreciate being among you. In fact, I
feel greatly indebted to you boys".
"You are a manly lot of young
men", he pursued. "You treat rue,
and everyone here, with deep respect and courtesy !"
"Because of that attitude which
You Hopkins men take you are the
law-abiding citizens of the state.
Not only that but you are the backbone and foundation of the University! (Cheers).
"You are," and he raised the arm
of the law above him, "the foundation and backbone not only of the
University but", enthusiastically
bringing the legal arm down upon
the rostrum, "the backbone and
foundation of the United States!"
(Cheers).
"Sarge" Waxes Eloquent

The sergeant rocked to and fro
on the platform as the ensuing din
began to recede. Waving a bony
finger above the audience like a
benediction he pointed out that "the
country is depending on you Hopkins men. (More cheers). Some
of the greatest men in the United
States have been educated at the
Johns Hopkins. Among them are
the late Woodrow Wilson and our
Present Governor, Albert C. Ritchie.
(Cheers).
"You have a great responsibility
Upon your shoulders. People are
looking up to you University men
for good advice and forward to
Your leadership of the country's activities in the future."

that always had a plethora of players and kibitzers are empty. The
clink of checkers is heard no more.
The tapping of Miss Martin's typewriter sounds as loud as the crack
of doom. It beats upon the walls
and echoes "Nevermore." The
music room is tenanted by a sparse
few lethargic souls, who, stretched
out on the chaise longues, snore
lustily to the croning strains of the
musical aviators.
But the library—oh! the library.
Here lies the key to the sphinx-like
atmosphere. Here are found human
beings (although Freshmen) and
here one hears the welcome sound
of speech. But it is a strange tone,
a low, serious tone, here and there
a dull, monotonous tone, as of
repeating a phrase. Heads are bent
low over 'books, and pencils fly
across sheets of virgin-white paper.
The dorms, too, offer a like view.
There are no loiterers about the
portals; no voices are raised in
hilarious song. Silence reigns supreme.
The pleasures of the flesh are
forgotten. Hopkins stands on the
brink of mid-years.

Auctioneer Glass; "Y" Stock
Exhausted
Raincoats, keys, books, secondhand hats, purses, odd gloves and
what-nots came into possession of
hopeful buyers last Tuesday as a
result of an auction held in Levering Hall. The stentorian tones of
Auctioneer Glass filled the lobby,
attracting crowds of prospective
customers and suckers, and ere long,
the lost and found department of
the "Y" was without its stock. in
trade.
Wide Range of Articles Sold

Articles which ranged from
ladies' purses at 2 cents to pairs of
gloves with four spares were dispensed with. One acquisitive student bought three hats, worth at
least five cents apiece, for 50 cents.
To be sure, he resold one of them
at private auction, realizing a profit
of 3 odd cents.
Raincoats were prominent at the
sale and brought as high as seventy
cents and as low as a quarter, at
which sum the buyer considered
himself hooked, owing to the condition of his purchase; and one man
is reported to have bought back his
own waterproof apparel.

PLAY SHOP PRODUCTION KSINESREPRESENTATIVE
SPEEDILY PROGRESSING TO INTERVIEW SENIORS
Cast For Three Plays Now
Being Chosen
TICKETS ON SALE
Setting Of Kirkley's Play Laid
In A Speakeasy
Under the direction of Bryllian
Fagin, instructor of the class in
play production given in the College for Teachers here, three oneact productions by Baltimore authors are slowly rounding into
shape for presentation. The plays
will be given on February 9, 12, 13
and 14.
The plays were chosen from fifty
one-act plays submitted in competition recently. Three have been
chosen. The writers of these plays
have at some time attended courses
at the Hopkins, and two are Flopkins graduates.
Kirkley's Play To Be Given

The play that has the first position on the program is "There Is
No Underworld," by Donald Kirkley, dramatic critic for The Baltimore Sun. Set in a speakeasy, it
is a satirical treatment of the theme
that there is no underworld. The
second presentation on the program,
which will perhaps be the most appreciated of the three is "Swing
Low," by Elmer Greensfelder. It
is a negro phantasy depicting a negro lynching scene. "Be Your Age,"
by Diana Rogge, which is a monologue originally written for use in
vaudeville and will be especially appreciative to a university audience
is last on the program.
Lester Haas Building Scenery

The preparation for the production of these plays are speedily being completed. Already the actress
for "Be Your Age" has been chosen
and Lester Haas, a member of the
Barnstormer Club, is constructing
the scenery for the presentations.

IN EXTRA PERIOD

Extra Period Declared

A five minute extra period was
agreed upon by the teams and with
supporters of both teams on their
feet, Western Maryland got the tipoff and Brown took a long shot.
The ball hit the backboard and
bounded oc, Brook getting it
and Hopkins taking it down the
floor. Taylor attempted a shot but
was fouled by Wellinger and took
two shots. The first was wide, but
the second went through giving
Hopkins the lead. Not satisfied
with this they proceeded to put the
game "on ice." Caleb Kelly got the
ball after the tip-off and passed to
his brother who put one in from
underneath the netting. Still determined to make sure of the contest, Caleb Kelly scored his seventh
goal from scrimmage. Not to be
outdone Don Kelly was fouled in
the act of shooting and made both
tries good. By this time Western
Maryland took to long shots and
Brown counted, but even with Wellinger's foul goal, this was insufficient and the whistle found the Jays
on the. long end of a 38-34 score.

feel greatly indebted to you boys".
"You are a manly lot of young
men", he pursued. "You treat rue,

You Hopkins men take you are the

"Sarge" Waxes Eloquent

The sergeant rocked to and fro
on the platform as the ensuing din
began to recede. Waving a bony
finger above the audience like a
benediction he pointed out that "the
country is depending on you Hopkins men. (More cheers). Some

States have been educated at the
Johns Hopkins. Among them are
the late Woodrow Wilson and our
Present Governor, Albert C. Ritchie.

Upon your shoulders. People are
looking up to you University men
for good advice and forward to
Your leadership of the country's activities in the future."

The pleasures of the flesh are
forgotten. Hopkins stands on the
brink of mid-years.

PLAY SHOP PRODUCTION KSINESREPRESENTATIVE
SPEEDILY PROGRESSING TO INTERVIEW SENIORS
Cast For Three Plays Now
Being Chosen
TICKETS ON SALE
Setting Of Kirkley's Play Laid
In A Speakeasy
Under the direction of Bryllian
Fagin, instructor of the class in
play production given in the College for Teachers here, three oneact productions by Baltimore authors are slowly rounding into
shape for presentation. The plays
will be given on February 9, 12, 13
and 14.
The plays were chosen from fifty
one-act plays submitted in competition recently. Three have been
chosen. The writers of these plays
have at some time attended courses
at the Hopkins, and two are Flopkins graduates.
Kirkley's Play To Be Given

The play that has the first position on the program is "There Is
No Underworld," by Donald Kirkley, dramatic critic for The Baltimore Sun. Set in a speakeasy, it
is a satirical treatment of the theme
that there is no underworld. The
second presentation on the program,
which will perhaps be the most appreciated of the three is "Swing
Low," by Elmer Greensfelder. It
is a negro phantasy depicting a negro lynching scene. "Be Your Age,"
by Diana Rogge, which is a monologue originally written for use in
vaudeville and will be especially appreciative to a university audience
is last on the program.
Lester Haas Building Scenery

The preparation for the production of these plays are speedily being completed. Already the actress
for "Be Your Age" has been chosen
and Lester Haas, a member of the
Barnstormer Club, is constructing
the scenery for the presentations.

JAY FIVE DEFEATS
WESTERN MARYLAND
IN EXTRA PERIOD

Extra Period Declared

A five minute extra period was
agreed upon by the teams and with
supporters of both teams on their
feet, Western Maryland got the tipoff and Brown took a long shot.
The ball hit the backboard and
bounded oc, Brook getting it
and Hopkins taking it down the
floor. Taylor attempted a shot but
was fouled by Wellinger and took
two shots. The first was wide, but
the second went through giving
Hopkins the lead. Not satisfied
with this they proceeded to put the
game "on ice." Caleb Kelly got the
ball after the tip-off and passed to
his brother who put one in from
underneath the netting. Still determined to make sure of the contest, Caleb Kelly scored his seventh
goal from scrimmage. Not to be
outdone Don Kelly was fouled in
the act of shooting and made both
tries good. By this time Western
Maryland took to long shots and
Brown counted, but even with Wellinger's foul goal, this was insufficient and the whistle found the Jays
on the. long end of a 38-34 score.

The Kelly family led the scoring
with Caleb counting seven field
goals for a total of fourteen points.
Not to be outdone Brother Don
'scored three from scrimmage and
made good on eight of his nine free
throws. Gunnett played well and the
floorwork of Siverman was again a
feature. The early part of the game
found the Jays lacking the dash and
pep of the Washington College fray
but this returned near the end of
the game.
Brown led the Western Maryland
team and was high point man of the
evening with sixteen points to his
credit. Clary counted seven also.
Western Maryland Freshmen
team took a 20-16 verdict from
the Hopkins Junior Varsity in the
preliminary setto.
